did.abstract: The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, correspondence, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, and memorabilia, dating from 1803 to 2007.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Packer Collegiate Institute records, 2014.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Packer Collegiate Institute, 2014.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note

The records were donated to Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) in 2014. In June 2015, BHS archivist John Zarrillo, assisted by Stephanie Coy, prepared the collection for transfer from Packer Collegiate Institute to BHS. This process included the consolidation of the collection from 445 boxes to 388 boxes. The collection's arrangement and description remained largely unchanged, although adjustments were made in certain areas to aid researchers. The Pratt Institute students generally authored the series and folder level descriptions, while the BHS archivist authored the record group level descriptions and administrative notes.
The finding aid and container list was converted from a Word document to an EAD XML file and imported into Archivists' Toolkit in July 2015.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute is one of the oldest, independent schools in New York City. Established in 1845 as the “Brooklyn Female Academy,” the Packer Institute plays a central role in the history of Brooklyn’s educational development. It all started when a committee formed by a group of leading citizens in the community recognized the need for female educational opportunities. At that time, Dr. Alonzo Crittenden presided over a student body of 350 girls from 19 states.

The school burned down on New Years’ Day, 1853, and reopened in 1854 with the assistance of a generous $65,000 gift—the largest donation to aid American secondary education at the time – from Mrs. Harriet Packer, widow of William Packer, and former trustee of the Female Academy. One condition of Packer’s donation was her request for the dissolution of the Female Academy Corporation replaced by what is today’s Packer Collegiate Institute. Prominent Brooklyn architect, Minard LaFever designed the Gothic Revival building, presently known as Founders Hall. The school’s boarding students included a number of Southern girls, many of whom remained at the Institute following the outbreak of the Civil War.

In 1883, after Crittenden’s death, Truman Backus assumed the role of Packer’s new president. As a result, religious studies ceased to be part of the curriculum. During this period, Packer rose to a position of national preeminence in female education. In 1887, the east wing, designed by Napoleon Le Brun, was built to house the gymnasium and science laboratories. In 1907, an Alumnae Hall was adjoined to the physical plant and the IRT began rumbling under Joralemon Street, which required the school to remove the observatory dome from the main building. Spanning the years from 1908 to1918, Edward Jasper Goodwin served as president and the students received letter grades for the first time. The Institute embraced Brooklyn’s increasing ethnic diversity and reflected the cultural shifts taking place throughout the city.

John Denbigh succeeded Goodwin and served as president until 1938, overseeing the 1926 addition of the penthouse in Alumnae Hall. Goodwin presided over a period that would define Packer’s Collegiate Program, beginning in 1919. Packer endured the financial impacts of the Great Depression, which resulted in teacher layoffs and salary cuts. In 1938 Paul Shafer became the fifth president of Packer and oversaw the Centennial celebration in 1945. During the 1950s, Packer’s Junior College, previously known as the Collegiate Division, began awarding Associate Degrees and in 1957, Pratt Hall was added to the physical plant. In 1968, President Shafer retired and Jack Skillman took over the post. In 1969, the school acquired St. Ann’s Church (Renwick &amp; Sands, 1867-69), which primarily houses classrooms.

By 1972, the Institute experienced major changes, including the disbandment of the Junior College in addition to the introduction of a co-ed student body. The Elementary school was divided into Lower and Middle schools during this decade and Peter Esty became Headmaster in 1982. Succeeding Esty was J. Geoffrey Pierson who served as the president of Packer from 1990 through 2004. Pierson oversaw the major renovation of the school’s physical plant. The renovation was completed in 2003 when Bruce Dennis became the Head of School in 2004.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The records are organized into 15 record groups:
Record Group F: Office of Public Relations
Record Group H: Development Office Records
Record Group K: Audio, Film, and Video Materials
Record Group O: Teacher, Student, and Alumni Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, correspondence, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, and memorabilia, dating from 1803 to 2007.

The records relate to the administrative and business activities of the Institute, including meeting minutes held between the Board of Trustees and other committees, annual reports from the President of Packer to the Board of Trustees, funding raising, and almuni affairs.

Student activities are well represented in the collection. Files related to students include student publications, theatrical programs, scrapbooks, student notebooks, numerous photographs, and audiovisual recordings.
Overall, the records document the history of women’s education in Brooklyn, New York, and the community’s rich cultural heritage.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Student records and personnel files are closed to researchers for 100 years from their date of creation. All other files are open to researchers without restriction.
The majority of the records in this collection are housed off-site. Please contact the BHS library for more information on the availibity of specific boxes ( library@brooklynhistory.org).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Copyright held by the Packer Collegiate Institute. All uses beyond fair use requires a licensing agreement as per Title 17 of the U.S. Copyright Law.
Photographs of individuals and records pertaining to individual students or staff cannot be reproduced for commercial purposes.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute collection (ARC.130) contains additional school publications and ephemera dating from 1846 to 2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains meeting minutes (Board of Trustees, teachers, and various committees), reports (from the President to Board of Trustees, evaluation reports, scholarship reports, and others), school catalogues, student records, and funding raising files, dating from 1844-2001.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into 16 series:
Series 1: Minutes of the Board of Trustees
Series 2: Minutes for Committee on Instruction
Series 5: Annual Reports of the President of the Packer Collegiate
Series 9: Student Handbooks, Pamphlets, and Programs
Series 10: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion
Series 11: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts

did.unittitle: Series 1: Minutes of the Board of Trustees

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Minutes of the Board of Trustees of Packer Collegiate Institute include information regarding admissions, finances, extracurricular issues, student and faculty life, alumni gifts and development, and issues pertaining to the operations and welfare of the school. Early dated minutes are handwritten and occasionally illegible. Some ledgers contain overlapping dates; however, the reason is unknown.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, with miscellaneous files placed at the end of the series.

Series 2: Minutes for Committee on Instruction

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Committee on Instruction meeting minutes document school related issues concerning faculty salaries, tuition rates, and graduation requirements. The minutes are contained in bound books and are in good, readable condition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series includes the minutes of the Academic and Collegiate Teachers’ Associations, Joint and Miscellaneous Teacher’s committees from the 19th century through the mid 20th century. The various faculty committee minutes provide insight into the inner-workings of the Institute drawn from the perspectives of faculty members. Additional materials including draft examination schedules, committee and subcommittee minutes, as well as letters to the Teachers’ Associations from students and staff are inserted/clipped/adhered into the pages of minutes.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by teachers’ organization, then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains minutes of regular meetings, reports of the Philanthropic Committee, House Committee reports, the report of the Committee for the Study of Co-education, the report of the Visiting Committee of Packer Collegiate Institute, and miscellaneous committee reports. The report of the Visiting Committee is a compilation of Packer’s self-evaluation and presents what the committee considers to be Packer’s accomplishments as well as recommendations for areas of improvements, i.e., new curtains, assembly room use, and curriculum expansion, among others.

did.abstract: Arranged chronologically with the inclusion of one cumulative report.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports on events that occurred during the school year such as additions to the pre-existing curriculum and field trips intended to prepare students for the SAT exam (1950-1951), which was introduced in 1949 by the College Exam Board. A report from 1938-1968 includes information regarding male admissions, added courses, extracurricular activities, and the damages from the 1964 fire. More recent reports contain information about financial donations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains three reports of the inspection of Packer’s Junior College for the purpose of receiving accreditation by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools (MSACS). The MSACS Commission of Institutions of Higher Education compiled two of the reports, and the third is a PCI self-evaluation. The reports detail observations and recommendations by PCI regarding its plans for the future and the fulfillment of its academic responsibilities. Topics include: setting, size, tradition, esprit de corps, purposes and objectives, programs, faculty, student services, library, admissions, alumni activities, and organization and administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Circular and Catalogues in both unbound and bound sets. There are approximately 400 Circular and Catalogues dating from 1846 to 1968. The Circular and Catalogues contain annual commencement exercises, lists of students and graduates, board of trustees, faculty and staff, and historical notations. The Supplement to the Catalogue, 1942 to 1968 contains information added to the Circular and Catalogue such as calendars and general interest events.

Series 9: Student Handbooks, Pamphlets, and Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The History of the Packer Collegiate Institute span the years 1853 –1928 and includes historical notations of Brooklyn’s heritage, Packer, the Board of Trustees, and past school presidents. “A Long Way Forward” is a reference to Packer.

The Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute, 1903-1941 includes the school constitution, by laws, committees, and members. The Charter and By Laws of the Packer Collegiate Institute contain similar information.

The Student Handbook and Guide to Efficient Study Habits include information about studying and general school rules. They also contain similar historical notations, calendars, and general interest events of the school.
Programs of musicals and plays that are included in this collection are “Women in History”, “Historical Cantata”, and “The Nations Offerings”, which is handwritten.

Series 10: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains the following:

Permanent Record of Promotions for 1869 & 1884; Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship c. 1883-1898 [possibly an incomplete series]; Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII. 26 ledgers.

Two bound ledgers titled Permanent Record of Promotions, 1869 & 1884 [academic transcripts]. Student transcripts including the year of promotion to each grade and graduation. Promotion dates circa 1860-1898.

Sixteen bound ledgers titled Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship [academic transcripts], dated between 1883 and 1898 [possibly an incomplete series]. Student transcripts include student name, age, address, grade level and scholarship in various subjects. Arranged alphabetically by last name of student. Additional students are included in the index. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which he/she was assigned, and the college to which the student was admitted, if any.

Eight bound ledgers titled Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship [academic transcripts] 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII. Student transcripts with student name, age, address, department and grade. Arranged alphabetically by last name. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded, as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which assigned, and college to which student was admitted, if any.

Series 11: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by surname. Loose photographs that were unidentifiable are filed at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the transcripts from The Packer Secondary School and Junior College. Each box contains between 23-60 folders, and each folder contains between 5-12 transcripts. The transcripts include some or all of the following information: Student grades, dates entered and left Packer, date of birth, home address, parent’s name(s), standardized test scores, extra-curricular activities, religious affiliation, and photographs. While most of the transcripts indicate if they are from either the Secondary School or the Junior College, there are some that remain ambiguous. There are records that contain information from both the Secondary School and the Junior College, and occasionally even Elementary School. Some transcripts show both maiden and married name if the student’s status changed while attending the school. In most cases, the record is filed by maiden name. However, there are a few records where the maiden name was crossed out and replaced by the married name, in which case it is filed by the married name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically by surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of student academic records, which were documented from approximately 1900-1960. Records include report cards, transcripts, teacher comments, parent/teacher/student/principal correspondence, student photographs, and various notes (e.g., religious background, DOB, parents’ names, academic standing). Most records are intact and legible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In 1948 Packer Institute sued the University of the State of New York contesting the university’s attempts to regulate the institute’s activities. The judge ruled in favor of Packer, ruling that only the state legislature had the right of oversight of Packer Institute. Materials include court transcripts and the judge’s official statement.

did.unittitle: Packer vs. University of the State of New York, et al

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of documents related to Packer fund drives, parent campaigns, annual gifts received, review and analysis of assets from various sources. For example, Endowment Funds, Centennial Funds, Capital Giving and solicitation from alumni, current student parents. Also included are suggestions for design renovations, in the form of brochures and ephemera like materials.

scopecontent.p: This series contains the Regents Examinations of Packer Collegiate Institute for the period between 1910 and 1950, with some gaps between June 1931 and 1938 and is missing the records for 1949. Information regarding student’s age, address and grades on examinations in academic courses are handwritten in the booklets. The examinations were administered by the principal and signed by the deputies of examination.

arrangement.p: The record group is organized into four series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains financial records relating to scholarships, fund raising, teacher pension funding, and the adminstration of the school, dating from 1849-1983.

physdesc.extent: in two boxes and three folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains correspondence between scholarship fund donors, their agents and staff members of Packer Institute, as well as copies of donor wills. The correspondence includes handwritten records of individual contributions to a variety of funds and scholarship programs, typed correspondence from donor attorneys, unofficial memos and cleared checks. In addition, overviews of various scholarships and miscellaneous financial records related to scholarships and funds are housed in file #1, Packer Scholarship Fund (general).

Report of Gifts Received, Volume II
Report of Gifts Received, Volume I
Report of Gifts Received, Volume II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is composed of material regarding the Emery Pension Fund, created by Mary M. Emery in memory of Adeline L. Jones in 1945 with a $50,000 gift in bonds to be used for the payment of pensions to retired teachers of the Institute. Included is correspondence regarding wording and modification of the fund, and copies of resolutions passed by Institute Board. The series also contains correspondence and meeting minutes regarding pensions 1928-1943; Pension Committee Meeting documents, 1912-1969; and a Retirement Plan Proposal, 1940.

physdesc.extent: in three boxes and three folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series provides an incomplete record of some of the Packer Institute’s income and expenditures between 1849-1961. The series contains miscellaneous fundraising and administrative budget materials, including ledgers for the Mrs. Packer Memorial Window Fund, 1906-1909; Treasurer's Reports, 1912-22; and the Administrative Budget, 1922-1934. It includes typewritten and bound minutes of the Institute's Committee on Finance, 1951-1968; and an itemized valuation of the Institute’s stock holdings as of February 2, 1955, which summarizes the division of the school’s $938,761.00 market investment, the bulk of which was committed to government bonds, public utilities, and chemical stocks. It also contains miscellaneous fundraising and administrative budget materials including an Annual Report of Brooklyn Female Academy, Nov. 16, 1849; a cash ledger, 1892-1904; the ledger for the Memorial Window fund, 1905-1906; the Backus Memorial Fund account book, 1908-1909; a plea for funds letter signed collectively by the board of trustees, 1917; Packer alumni pledge cards, 1917; an Endowment fund ledger, 1917-1921; check stubs, 1926-1932; and Centennial Fund documents, 1945-1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group documents various alterations, renovations, and new construction at PCI, dating from 1881-1995. It includes plans, specifications, blueprints, correspondence, and related files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The plan books and specifications document a variety of alterations, building additions, and demolitions undertaken at Packer in 1909, 1940, 1944, and 1957. The materials in the series affords researchers a vantage from which to better understand the architectural evolution of the campus at 170 Joralemon Street. Of special interest are: Architect William Tubby’s specifications and instructions for the major alterations performed before World War I; James Gamble Rogers’ materials and plans for the building’s subsequent overhaul in 1940; the promotional materials describing proposed additions to mark Packer’s centennial celebration in 1945; and intensive specifications describing the large-scale alterations performed in 1957 by Champan, Evans, and Delehanty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains architectural drawings, blueprints, floor plans, and projected renderings prepared by the Chapman, Evans, and Delehanty firm. The materials document the extensive alterations and additions made to the Packer Collegiate Institute in 1957 and 1958. The various renderings and blueprints provide detailed information on Chapman’s alterations. Large-scale floor plans of the entire campus are filed, as well as specific treatments of such areas as the dining room, gymnasium, sundeck, library, and greenroom.

The series also includes drawings and blueprints created by various firms as proposals for the installation of the institute’s steam heating system circa 1882. It is unclear which, if any of the firms, actually won the contract. Dated the same year is a correspondence from Otis Brothers & Company regarding the installation of an electric elevator. The company provided Packer with a blueprint for this elevator on June 5, 1891. The series also contains architectural blueprints and watercolors from 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains files related to two PCI presidents, Truman Jay Backus and Paul Shafer. The Backus series is primarily composed of correspondence, while the Shafer series contains more administrative files.

physdesc.extent: in two boxes and nine folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes two significant sets of correspondence. The first is correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908), President of the Faculty at Packer Collegiate Institute from September 1883 through March 1908. The range of topics covered in this correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908) includes scholastic accommodations and referrals for students, scholarship recommendations, faculty accommodations, and recommendations for teacher applicants and administrative matters such as building maintenance and facilities.

The series has been broken into four sub-series that include: 1) Multiple Correspondences arranged alphabetically by name; 2) General Correspondence between teachers; 3) Chronological files; and 4) Biographical/Memorabilia of Truman J. Backus

Highlights from this series include correspondence with William C. Lawton which constitutes a full exchange between Lawton and Dr. Backus about a teaching position, including interesting professional negotiations. Mr. Lawton did not end up teaching at the school. Noteworthy are the teacher recommendations made to Backus by Miss Lucy M. Salmon, Associate Professor of History at Vassar.

Additional materials include a folder containing correspondence between Backus and members of the Board of Trustees including letters from Board member Seth Low (1850-1916), who was the Mayor of Brooklyn from 1881-1885 and served as the President of Columbia University from 1890-1901. It also includes a six-page letter from Mr. McKeen, board member, in opposition to recommendations to the board to increase tuition. Also of noted significance is the last folder in the sub-series: correspondences between parents and Dr. Backus (1882-1891). The topics covered in this set include parental concerns over scarlet fever, scholarships, and lunch dismissals.

Contains letters between Truman J. Backus and members of the teaching faculty. There is a letter written by Backus to the teaching staff asking for their opinions on the usage of the phrases “awfully bad” and “awfully pretty” (1900) and several responses from the teaching staff.

In addition, an eight-page letter from the Committee on Instruction (1899) regarding the possible reduction in teaching staff; a twenty page Report from Dr. Backus to the Committee on Instruction (1886) regarding curriculum; reports from Miss Susan K. Cook, teacher of “Mental and Moral Philosophy”; a report on individual teacher performance and recommendations about changes in assignments for teachers. This final report provides instructions on teaching etiquette accompanied by a 3 page statistical report.
Includes folders that span the years 1883-1894 with the exception of 1893. Includes one folder, undated.

Contained in this subseries are 1) Published items written by Dr. Backus and 2) Biographical material about Dr. Backus. There is a short pamphlet written by Dr. Backus entitled: “Various Phases of an Important Subject” pertaining to the education of Blacks in the South, published by American Missionary Association, 12 pages. This sub series also contains a memorial essay written about the school’s founder, Harriet Packer by Dr. Backus, and describes the education of young women in Brooklyn, in addition to detailing the first meeting between Dr. Backus and Mrs. Packer.

physdesc.extent: in five boxes and two folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains assorted materials from Packer Collegiate Institute’s President Dr. Paul Shafer, 1938 – 1968.

The first group of materials consists of speeches delivered to students, faculty, parents and/or alumni by Dr. Shafer between 1930-1953. The speeches address WWII and its impact on education. Speeches following WWII are addressed to the PTA and focus on education within the home. Two examples of Shafer's writings appear in print outside of the Packer community: Forbes Magazine and Vital Speeches of the Day. A large formal document, with the signature and official seal of New York City’s Mayor, Fiorello H. LaGuardia, and names Shafer a trustee of the Brooklyn Public Library. Shafer's 1967 announcement of his retirement is also included in the series by the Alumni Association. Materials are in good condition, although, Vital Speeches of the Day magazine’s condition is deteriorating and should be handled with care.

The bulk of this series consists of Dr. Shafer's office files. Arranged in rough chronological order for the academic years between 1960-1967. Folders include: Annual Report, Daily Program, Finances, School Organization and Administration and Teacher Reports. Information contained in these folders is not consistent by year. The original folder labels are unclear throughout the series. Folder items detail Dr. Shafer’s philosophy of education, his leadership style and his thoughts regarding topical issues pertaining to the school as a whole. The format of materials ranges from printed programs to handwritten notes on 4 x 7 colored note cards. The materials are in fair to good condition. Carbon copies require special handling.

The Annual Report folders contain President Shafer's notes in preparation of his reports to the Board of Trustees. The Daily Program folders contain Dr. Shafer's notes for addresses to groups including the Board of Trustees, faculty, and students at the beginning of the each school year. Many notes are typed with handwritten edits while others are handwritten. There are printed programs for school events such as theater performances or the Christmas Carol Sing. There are minutes from meetings of the Board, and there are lists such as, "Colleges entered by graduates of the Academic School."

The Finance Reports are inconsistent between 1960 and 1968. The Treasurer of the Board of Trustees is responsible for delivering these reports detailing school expenses for events such as theater performances or the Spring Concert.

The School Administration and Organization folders contain items dealing with campus life and the President's responsibilities. Some items are related to the faculty such as a description of the school's Major Medical Insurance policy coverage and a list of new teachers, or instructions, such as "Procedures for Examinations." Some items detail student life, for example Permission Slip forms for a school dance or a directive regarding the lapsed enforcement of rules prohibiting girls from leaving school between the times of arrival and dismissal. Miscellaneous items include air raid drill instructions and a list of families with two or more children in the school.

The Teachers' Report folders are comprised of evaluations by faculty members, reports on the activities school clubs and reports from the dean and department heads. Among the materials are mimeographed examples of class assignments and exams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record contains materials from Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer, Miss Harriet P. Packer, and Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer Jr.

Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer, Founder, 1853-1958. This record group contains Mrs. W.S.’s correspondences and a journal. The correspondence to and from Mrs. Packer covers a wide variety of topics. Mrs. Packer’s journal details a trip to Europe taken between May and August of 1854. The journal remains in good condition although Mrs. Packer’s handwriting is difficult to decipher in places.

Also included in this series is a speech about Mrs. Packer by Mrs. Truman Jay Backus. The speech provides a description of Mrs. Packer’s character, her plight for women’s education, and her vision of the Packer School.

Miss Harriet P. Packer, correspondence between 1903-1912. Contents include a transcript of a speech delivered by Miss Harriet P. Packer, daughter of Mrs. W.S. Packer, detailing the history of Packer Institute’s jubilee celebration. There are numerous letters regarding Miss Packer’s death in 1909.

Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer, Jr. correspondence between 1893-1917. Materials include a set of memoirs written by Mrs. Mary K. Packer. The memoirs describe the impacts of the Civil War on the school, and family events such as the meeting with Mr. W.S. Packer Jr., her subsequent engagement and marriage to him. Historical information dealing with the aftermath of the Civil War: John Browns raid, the nomination of Abraham Lincoln, the first Battle of Bull Run, Gettysburg, are the main subjects of individual chapters.

It also includes correspondence between Mrs. Packer and Mary discussing her attempt at attending college after a long period of absence due to poor health. The correspondence depicts a college bound curriculum.

Record Group F: Office of Public Relations

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into five series:
Series 2: Press Releases, Photographs, and Publicity Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group is composed of files maintained by the PCI Office of Public Relations. These include administrative files, press releases, photographs, clippings, scrapbooks, along with event programs (graduations/commencements, class day, founder's day, centennial, etc.) and related files. The records date from 1845-2002.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials generated by and produced for the Office of Public Relations. The items include interoffice memos among staff; correspondence between staff and advertisers, newspapers, educational directories, as well as correspondences between the Public Relations office and faculty, parents, and students. In addition are minutes from weekly meetings and school related conventions. Other materials included: programs and academic schedules, various office items such as calendars, handouts, scratch paper, bills, school histories, newsletters, and memos concerning school lectures and events. The majority of the materials are in very good condition.

This series represents materials primarily from the 1970s, 1980s, and the early 1990s. There are a few documents that date before 1970; however, there are notes of interest from the American College Public Relations Association, 1954-1962. Other files of include the invitation and program for the 125th Anniversary program on November 7, 1970.

Series 2: Press Releases, Photographs, and Publicity Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to press releases and photos of school events; promotional brochures; faculty, student, honorees, and alumni announcements and information; documentation of school policies; and publicity materials produced by Packer such as postcards, greeting cards, and calendars. The majority of the materials are in good condition.

The decades highlighted in this series include the 1960s, 1980s, and early 1990s. There is little in this series from the 1970s aside from the press releases and correspondence for Packer’s 125th Anniversary Celebration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains press clippings, articles, and advertisements found in various local and national newspapers, journals, and directories related to Packer Institute. The clippings contain general information about the Institute; sporting events, theatre productions, music concerts, dance productions, faculty and student achievements and awards, alumni news, PTA events, and faculty memorials. Other materials are clippings related to community events, student activities, brochures, and articles on the subject of teaching.

The majority of the information dates from the 1980s early 1990s. There is little information on the decades prior to the 1970s. Two noteworthy materials describing Packer’s early years are clippings found in the Brooklyn Daily Eagle in 1890, along with a copy of Brooklyn Life, dated September 6, 1902.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains general information about the school and school policies; publicity materials such as postcards, greeting cards, and calendars. The majority of the materials are in good condition.

Time periods with the most available information represented in this series are the 1960s, 1980s, and early 1990s. There is less information in this series from the 1970s, but a topic of interest would be the press releases and correspondence for Packer’s 125th Anniversary Celebration.

Series contains scrapbooks maintained by Packer Institute staff members and include, newspaper clippings, photographs, letters, and programs pertaining to the students, faculty, alumni, and school events. Most newspaper clippings are taken from Brooklyn publications such as the Brooklyn Eagle and other Packer publications. The series holds some mounted newspaper clippings in addition to loose scrapbook pages. The earlier scrapbooks from 1848-1920s are in fragile condition, but the contents within these scrapbooks have been maintained in good condition.

While the majority of the scrapbooks focus on miscellaneous events, some are subject focused, i.e., the 1848 scrapbook relating to Packer’s class day and commencement. The dates represented by the institutional scrapbooks range from 1848-1930s. There are no scrapbooks from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The items in the series pertain to Packer Collegiate Institute anniversary celebrations, along with other school related annual and special events. The materials cover events ranging from commencement ceremonies, Packer’s 75th Anniversary Exhibition, College Day, Class Day, concerts, receptions, lectures, conferences, dedications (i.e., Katherine Sloan Pratt Hall, 1958) and other school organizations (i.e., PTA functions).
Included in this series are programs, invitations, songs, seating arrangement, correspondence, sermons (for annual commencement), and booklets (i.e. History of Packer, 1853-1928).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group generally documents student activities at PCI from 1852-2000. It includes numerous student publications, student notebooks and scrapbooks, and an extensive collection of theater production files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into four series:

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title, then chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include issues from the following literary, artistic, and news publications:
All True Tales (autobiographical comic strips, 1988)
Packer Current Items (literary magazine, 1909-2000)
Packer Fagots (literary magazine, 1890-1895)
The First Act (student newspaper, 1921-1922)
The Literary Novice (Brooklyn Heights Seminary literary magazine, 1854)
Middle School Poetry Anthology (literary magazine, 1987)
The Neophyte (literary magazine, 1860-1861)
PALM: Packer Alternative Literary Magazine (literary magazine, 1990s)
The Packer Perspective (student newsletter, 1971-1972)
The Packer Press (student newspaper, 1955-1965)
The Phoenix (literary magazine, 1867-1868)
The Packer Prism (student newspaper, 1971-1973 and 2000-2001)
The Packer Quarterly (literary magazine, 1868-1879)
School Room Echoes (literary magazine, 1853)
Something Normal (Zine, 1986)
Underwater: A Collection of Middle School Poetry (literary magazine, 1988)
Some of the 19th century publications are:
School Room Echoes (1853), The Literary Novice (1854), The Neophyte (1860-1861), The Phoenix (1867-1868), The Packer Quarterly (1868-1879), and Packer Fagots (1890-1895).

Issues of The Literary Novice from the Brooklyn Heights Seminary are dated May 19, October 6, October 30, November 3, November 17, and December 15, 1854. These issues were sent to Mrs. Harold Quantin at Packer in 1943. It is uncertain whether the Brooklyn Heights Seminary is the Packer Institute, the Brooklyn Female Academy, or another school in the neighboring areas.

Packer Current Items was first published in 1909 – a copy of vol. 1, issue 1 is included in this series. The publication continued into the twenty-first century, marking it as the longest-running student publication at Packer. Date, volume and issue numbers are sometimes inconsistent. A few issues are missing (see container list for details). Also included in this series is correspondence from various alumni regarding the 50th anniversary issue of Packer Current Items, which was celebrated in 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains notebooks, scrapbooks, and autograph books created by students, either individually or as part of a group. The books include clippings, photos, essays, ephemera, programs, and class notes. Materials document student experience while attending Packer and are of academic or social nature. Other materials were created by former graduates and often include updates on alumni. The Goldenbook is an unbound scrapbook compiled by the class of 1901 shortly after their 50th reunion. The scrapbook of Packer graduate, Mrs. Paul D. Shafer (1940s-1950s) primarily contains information and clippings about her husband. Mrs. Harriet Pecket Cabbage’s scrapbook contains updates on members of her class (1901), including correspondences and family information, including birth and death dates. The 1893 scrapbook of Louise Van Arden contains a letter from Florence Nightingale congratulating Van Arden on her graduation. Beatrice Eddy’s notebooks are academic and include art/architecture information, possibly from her experience studying abroad. Student notebooks also include individual class notes and class meeting minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains information pertaining to Packer Institute’s yearly theater productions. Student productions were split into senior and junior performances during the theater’s later years. Most of the images, press coverage, and papers in the series collection address senior productions unless otherwise noted. The students staged a Christmas Pageant every year that included a theatrical reenactment of the Nativity. In addition, repertory and modern productions were performed in the early spring of each year. The stage sets were built and the performances directed by students with adult guidance. In 1979, Packer Theater celebrated its 125th Anniversary by hosting “Today & Yesterday.” For publicity purposes, retrospective material was collected about past theater productions for the Packer “Pelican” yearbook. Contents relating to individual plays vary, ranging from photographs and news clippings to promotional material, playbills, personal notes, and stage budgets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains records produced and/or maintained by the PCI Development Office, dating from 1870-2007. They include files relating to the faculty, curriculum, graduation, and Packer College. It also includes issues of the Packer Alumna and Packer Magazine.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into five series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files on individual faculty members, as well as faculty events and clubs. The dates of the material range from the 1910s through the 2000s (bulk 1910s-1960s). There is no way to determine whether or not all members of the faculty from this period are included in the series. An original, incomplete finding aid that includes dates through 2006 for faculty members containing name, subject taught, and date of death can be found at the beginning of the series.

Included in this series are correspondences between faculty members; the writings of faculty members; newspaper clippings; personal letters and obituaries. The majority of faculty files are composed of information questionnaires and/or the initial employment applications. Individual faculty files of particular interest are Caroline Chesebrough, a 19th century writer; Bruce Tulloch, former Director of the Upper school; Eleanor Bannister, class of 1875 and distinguished artist who painted many portraits of Packer notables; Alex Bernstein, son of Leonard Bernstein; and Stephen Koplowitz, professional dancer/choreographer and director of Packer’s dance program from 1984 onward.

The miscellaneous faculty files (placed at the end of the series) include invitations, flyers, letters, “people at Packer brochures,” clippings, and faculty narratives. Of particular interest is the Faculty Shop Club ledger and minute books that outline activities and expenditures, including thank you notes from gift recipients.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to extracurricular activities that concentrate on both the students and alumni of the Packer Collegiate Institute. The original folders were labeled “Curriculum Articles” and arranged according to specific programs, but also contained unrelated material. Most of the original order was preserved. Additionally, the materials within each folder are arranged in reverse chronological order by date for added convenience in searching. Each folder contains clippings from internal and external publications, programs, flyers and registration forms relating to community service, culture, and events at the school. Of interest are some of the photos, negatives and programs from Packer productions such as the “Dance Concert Programs” and other student productions. According to the Packer Institute website, the “Dance Concert Programs” are the only performing arts event at Packer that feature original student work every year for the past 23 years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A large percentage of the files in this series pertain to Packer College, which closed in 1972. Items include: sample forms and letters used by the admissions department; President Skillman’s letter announcing the closing of Packer College; and various studies and requests for information. Of particular note are the closing notifications, 1971-72 and closing response letters, and 1972 folders that chronicle the suspension of the collegiate program at Packer.

Other items include: Guidelines for the acceptance and entrance of non-matriculated students, foreign student forms, foreign student files 1957-66, including applications, forms and information. Disadvantaged student forms, American Council on Education Bill to Amend Higher Education Act of 1965, a College Work study Manual 1966, the “Campus Disturbance Report” that includes a statement entitled “Violence and Disruption on the U.S. Campuses from 1968-1969” by Adam E. Bayer and Alexander W. Astin that was issued by the American Council on Education in 1969.

Other materials consist of a “Bill of Rights” for students by Patricia Curtis. The historical significance of these documents exists on both a personal and local level as visible signs of the disruption of campuses by students protesting the war in Vietnam and Civil Rights issues as well as the “tragic events at Kent State University which sharply intensified their feelings and sense of need.” – taken from Rights of the Student, “Confidentiality of Student Records.”

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains PCI Alumni records, dating from 1848 to 2002. It includes a large set of alumni questionnaires for the Classes of 1848 to 2002, files and photographs relating to alumni reunion luncheons (1911-2002), files relating to regional alumni group chapters (1911-1997), and files relating to alumni-student relations (1995-2001).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically by class year and alphabetically by name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains alumni questionnaires for the classes 1848 through 2002. Some files also contain alumni correspondence, news clippings, photographs, wills and testaments, and miscellaneous material (e.g. keepsakes albums, invitations, commencement programs, class materials, theater programs, and relating to alumni activities). Records regarding alumni funds, donations, bankbooks, correspondence relating to financial support of the institution are also included here. One unique item in this series is a birthday note written on birch bark by Mary Bond (class of 1886), dated 1901. Highlights include alumni information on notable students such as Mary White Ovington (1890), one of the early founders of what is now the NAACP; Elizabeth Woodbridge (1890), one of the first women to receive a PhD from Yale University; Ruth St. Denis (1898), pioneer modern dancer (nee Ruth Dennis); Lucy Burns (1899), suffragette; Janet Gale (1929), Pro-Choice Activist for Planned Parenthood; Nancy (Charlotte) Cushman (1933), Broadway actress; Sybil Hart Kooper (1945), Judge; Carin Vilonen, Miss Finlandia of 1966; Nancy Goliger (1968), Director of Adelphi University; and Maria Yatrakes (1999), Greek Olympic soccer player.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains many photographs in a wide variety of formats, including, but not limited to, black-and-white and color prints, negatives, glass lantern slides, carte-de-visites, and 35 mm slides. In addition to loose photographs, the record group includes a number of photographic albums and scrapbooks, most of which were assembled by students. The images span the history of the school, from the 1840s to 2004. Topically, the record group documents students (incuding individual portraits, class portraits, various school events, and activities), administrators and faculty, and Packer buildings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The items in this series are photographic albums, mainly containing portraits of students of the Packer Institute, as well as a few portraits of Packer faculty members and occasionally shots of the Packer facility. These albums generally belonged to students from the classes represented. The albums range in date from 1864 to 1993, though the bulk of the material is from to 1870s to the 1890s.

It also contains photographs of classroom activities and field trips for fourth graders at Packer Institute. All photographs were transferred from their original albums; one album per year (1985-1993).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Packer Institute yearbook materials, dating from the early 1970s through 2000, with a significant portion focusing on the years between 1990-1992. Material formats include slides, negatives, contact sheets, collages, and artwork, but primarily, materials are photographs. Most photographs are labeled with a small tag indicating on which page they were to be placed in the yearbook printout. Some materials are undated. Photographs are in both black and white and color and include individual and group subjects. Subjects for materials include students engaged in class activities, sports and recreational activities, arts and performance pursuits, and formal classroom portraits. While the subjects are primarily students, the faculty and staff of Packer are featured in both individual shots, group shots, and as participants in student activities. There are photographs, slides, and negatives focused exclusively on the Packer building and grounds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains photographic materials of Packer Institute school-related events dating from 1846 to the mid-1990s with the highest concentration of dates in the 1970s and 1980s.

Pumpkin Patch, May Day, Founder’s Day, and Country Fair celebrations are popular themes of these materials with dates ranging from the 1960s through the early 1980s. Other events include a Dracula school play, concert performances, and alumnae chapter meetings in the 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a 5x4” daguerreotype mounted in a leather case of Packer Collegiate Institute namesake William Packer with oxidation around the edges. A mounted portrait contains a paper binder label “Photograph of A.A. Low, patented July 8th, 1890”, included with 42 copies of the same portrait all signed “very truly yours, A.A. Low” contain some foxing, and one copy is detached from a book with the running title “The Packer Collegiate Institute”. Two portraits of President Paul Shafer, 11x8.5, one housed in a paper mount, the other labeled “1964, Paul D. Shafer”, are both in good condition. Mounted with glue to a paper sheet are five black and white photographs from 1971 of faculty, labeled Mr. Fink, Mr. O’Leary, Mr. Curtis, Miss Osborne (missing), and Miss Dennig, and one unlabeled candid student photograph, containing some scratches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of 35mm color slides taken of Packer Institute, as well as events that have taken place there and the people that have shaped the school over the years. The slides are organized into building images, people, artwork/slideshows and events. The folders are arranged chronologically and range from reproductions of 1880s photographs to the 1990s. The bulk of the material is in the “People” section, most of which is within the 1980s and 1990s. Class images, classrooms scenes and candid shots of students and faculty are contained within this area. “Events” (ranging from 1950s to the 1990s) include special events like May Day, field trips, graduations, class days and sports, and the 1987 Commencement with speaker Mayor Ed Koch. The “Building” section contains interior and exterior images of and around Packer Institute ranging from 1956-1996. It also includes photographs of the building renovation.

did.unittitle: Series 8: Individual and Group Student Photographic Portraits

physdesc.extent: in seven boxes and six folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains individual class photographic portraits of Packer students from class years ranging from 1867 to 1912. There are 864 individual portraits, approximately 438 cabinet cards, 387 cartes-de-visites, 4 tintypes, and 35 photographs. Many of the photographs are identified and dated. Overall, the photographs are in fair to good condition and can be viewed. Includes the photographs donated by: Mrs. Clifford Keep from 1874, Mrs. Bertha Richardson from 1875, Mrs. Judith E Wallingford from 1876, Mrs. Lulu M. Snyder from 1889, and Irene M. Biertenshaw from 1912.

Additionally, the series contains of group class photographic portraits from 1871-1990s; the class of 1880 reunion on May 12, 1937; photographs from the Packer Glee Club of 1898 with various items of ephemera, and notes and invitations from the 1896 commencement; miscellaneous notes from 1843-1853; and contact sheets with negatives of students dating from 1980-1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographic materials dated 1871, 1893-1898, 1913, 1979-1981, and 1991-2005, and contains photographs documenting Packer Collegiate Institute's student and faculty events and activities. In addition to photographs, the series also includes corresponding negatives, contact sheets, slides and photo compact discs. The photographs contained within are both black and white and color. The activities documented include such things as sports, alumni activities, and student performances such as plays, talent shows and choir concerts. The photographs also document field trips to various Brooklyn institutions. Additionally, they record campus activities such as gardening, fairs and class projects. These photographs shed light on the types of unique activities that are presents at Packer Collegiate Institute and record numerous students and faculty during this era.

Please note: many file descriptions include a five-digit, hyphenated number as part of the file description. These numbers are formatted XX-YYY, in which XX is a year indicator and YYY a sequential indicator. Thus, 98-002 indicates that the envelope is labeled as being from 1998, and is the second sequentially in its order, after 98-001 and before 98-003. These numbers were found on the envelopes in which the photographs were stored, and have been preserved to aid in the location of materials. However, they should be relied upon only with the understanding that not all photograph envelopes came with such a number, and thus the sequential ordering should be considered in no way absolute. In the instance that two photograph envelopes were found to possess the same numerical code, the two envelopes were designated within the file descriptions as variants (A) and (B) of the same five-digit code (ex: 98-002A and 98-002B).

Record Group K: Audio, Film, and Video Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record groups contains audiovisual media in a variety of formats, including VHS tapes, Betamax tapes, Hi8 tapes, 3/4 inch tapes, 16 mm film reels, and audio cassettes. Contents of the record group vary, and include events (especially graduation ceremonies), interviews with students, educational films, teacher seminars, and promotional videos. The tapes and reels date from 1933 to 2002.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into four series:
Series 1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production

did.unittitle: Series 1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Packer Institute’s Day in the Life school production materials. Arranged by material type, this series covers a time span of 1995-1996, with a significant portion highlighting 1995. A Day in the Life series highlights interview questions and discussions asked to a select 17 students and staff at Packer Institute to show the impact of Packer on their lives as well as show how they impact life at Packer. Interviewees are asked about academics, extracurricular activities, the building and grounds, interactions with students and faculty, and every day occurrences at Packer.

The 17 students and faculty interviewed for this production were: Erin Burke, Simone Callendar, Garfield Davidson, Abigail Hooper, Peter Kelly, Vanessa Olivieri, Chartey Quanceo, Susan Roos, Alliyah Rosenthall, Cynthia Rothschild, Ken Rush, Barbara Seadon, Denise Schweid, Ben Shopsin, Sueta Srinivasen, Laura Zinck, and Erland Zygmuntowicz.

Materials and Condition: Media formats include beta video tapes, Sony digital audio tapes, Hi8 tapes, and industrial 3/4 inch tapes. A majority of the media used for this production was recorded by Winton DuPont Films. There are also film scripts and interview questions which are both on camera and off, and production notes. Film scripts are in good condition and transcribed by Herman S. Jaffe. Interview questions and production notes are both highlighted and written on.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 16mm films owned by the Packer Collegiate Institute. Materials range from footage of Packer events to educational films used in Packer classrooms. Included in the collection are four Kodak mailing packages, which may help to date some of the undated film reels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The audio cassettes in this series are roughly divided into four categories. Included in the collection are various graduations and ceremonies throughout the years at Packer. For example, the introduction ceremony for Geoffrey Pierson in 1990. In addition, there are tapes documenting important seminars: ATIS (Association of Teachers of Independent Schools), meetings as early as 1980, NAIS (National Association of Independent Schools), on the role of the arts in education, and yearly NAIS meetings. Copies of a 1977 performance of Gilbert & Sullivan’s Ruddigore, and a teacher’s clarinet concert are among the series performance section. Finally, the miscellaneous material includes one tape in which the connection to Packer is unclear – a radio show playing music from the 1950s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The VHS tapes have been roughly divided into five categories: Ceremonies (graduation, May Day), dating as early as 1989. These videotapes document various graduation ceremonies at Packer. Promotional videos contain footage from unedited clips to more formal promotional products that may have been sent out to prospective students and their parents. Clips display images of the Packer building; children engaged in classes, general student life, and class presentations. Also included are News and Slice-of-Life broadcasts Packer students and faculty have been interviewed for various local news features, and have made a few headlines themselves. This collection also includes a news broadcast in Japanese. The Seminars section of the collection includes tapes documenting National Fund-Master seminars. The miscellaneous collection includes a few tapes in which the connection to Packer is unclear such as a performance at Carnegie Hall and a videotape of a WWF (World Wrestling Federation) match, and a John Gray Presentation.

Video and audio quality ranges from poor to very good, from amateur to professional quality. There seems to be no consistency in the video documentation in terms of scope or date. That said, the material covers a range of different types of events and Packer-related news stories.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into four series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains instructional material, primarily from the 19th century. It includes glass lantern slides depicting assorted locations and attractions, monographs (textbooks), nature cards depicting various plants and animals, and photo cards which survey the history of western art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains 69 glass lantern slides. The slides are dated approximately between 1880s to the early 1900s. The lantern slides depict assorted locations and attractions taken at various times of the year in and around the United States (Niagara Falls; Yosemite Park; Old Faithful; Bee Hive Geyser, WY; a glacial fjord in Maine; a grain elevator in Illinois; a United State Navy warship; Luray Caverns, Virginia; Continental Divide and Grand Canyon, Colorado), Africa (DeBeers mine in South Africa; a caravan in Biskra, Algeria), Ireland (a peat bog in Killarney), and Australia (Tasmanian Forest).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: No apparent order was found when processing. In order to aid researchers in locating slides of similar content, it is arranged alphabetically (by location if applicable) with multiple lantern slides of the same location filed next to one another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains antiquarian textbooks that were used for instruction. The books vary in size but are of a general quarto (8-12 inches) or octavo (6-9 inches) size and shape. The subjects are educational and include geography, history, and English studies. The publication dates range from 1803 to 1883. One title is stamped by Packer in 1908.

(No Author). How to Use Globes in the School and Family, 1859, AH Andrews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains instructional nature cards depicting plants and animals, including varieties of wild cats, birds, roses and others. The 104 cards are printed on approximately 3x4 inch cardstock in vibrant full watercolor, and are in near perfect condition. Images are clear, not damaged and are encapsulated in mylar in pairs. Each card is stamped with the date 1873. The cards are in order of their natural family and species. Those depicting animals give a perspective side view and include small diagrams of jaws and feet for identification. The plants are shown from a top/side view of the plant and shown in full bloom. All cards are mounted on black card stock with a descriptor on the back of the plant or animal pictured.

did.unittitle: Letter of Introduction. Quadrupeds-Wild Cats-Carnivores, 11 cards. Plants-Pink Family, 11 cards
Birds-Swimmers, 9 cards. Birds-Scratchers, 8 cards. Hollow Horn-Chewers (Cattle), 10 cards
Birds of Prey, 10 cards. Squirrel Family- Gnawers, 12 cards. Rose Family, 12 cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains 143 photo cards, which are photographs or prints mounted on heavy mat board. Images are mounted in both landscape and portrait orientation and vary in size. Mat board dimensions are predominately between 9x12 - 11x14 inches. Several prints are without mounting, all have been encapsulated. These photo cards were likely employed as visual aids in the teaching of a survey of western art and were often sold as thematic albums. The dates of use were likely during the last quarter of the 19th century through the early 1900s. The subjects of most of the images are Renaissance and Baroque art, including architecture (cathedrals, sculpture, plans, and elements), sculpture, paintings, and sacred decorative objects (reliquaries). Photographs were taken at the sites where their subject was created or resided at the time, which was primarily throughout northern Italy (Florence, Siena, Lucca, Pisa, and Venice). Many of the photographs include a caption or have a label fixed to mat board. A number of photo cards include maker’s mark, the most prevalent being Alinari, the first and largest provider of these materials specific to the subject.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is arranged into two series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains an assortment of Packer related memorabilia, including awards, plaques, textiles (banners, uniforms, flags, etc.), pins, other artifacts, and ephemera. It also includes items which were used in exhibitions which were displayed at the school. The items in the record group date from 1839 to 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of artifacts and memorabilia related to the Packer Collegiate Institute spanning the years 1853-2004. The boxes include awards and commemorations presented to students, printed material related to commencement exercises and curricula, personal items belonging to former students, and architectural memorabilia. Items of note include an assortment of historical flags and banners dating as far back as 1890, as well as jewelry bearing the school insignia, school uniforms, garden plaques and a Packer Institute picture book that includes archival depictions of Brooklyn. Some materials were donated by Mrs. T. Stewart Harris in 2001 and Ms. Mary Jean Eckhardt Howard (class of 1946).

Record Group O: Teacher, Student, and Alumni Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The record group contains papers which belonged to former teachers, students, and alumni of Packer, dating from 1865 to 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The record group is organized into three series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence and manuscripts, along with a smaller quantity of poems and plays by the author. The bulk of material in this collection dates from 1924 to 1927, when Alice Van Vliet studied and received honors in Classical Moderations at Oxford University in England and toured around post-WWI Europe. Van Vliet documented her experiences in a travel journal and letters that she composed to a large group of friends back in America.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Alice Van Vliet was an American, born on January 11, 1874, and died at age 61 on September 6, 1935. The first available reference to Alice Van Vliet is from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle newspaper, which reported that in 1898 Van Vliet was a teacher at the Berkeley Institute (now the Berkeley Carroll School), an all-girls school started in 1886 in Brooklyn, New York. Following this, she was a Latin teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute from 1901 to 1905. Van Vliet is listed as a reader for the College Entrance Examination in 1906, where her title is given as “Director of Latin and Greek” at Packer, and she is credited with holding an A.B. from the University of Chicago, granted 1896. The last known teaching position that Van Vliet occupied was in 1926 and 1927 at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California.

A book of Van Vliet’s poetry entitled Poems was published in 1937, two years after her death. The dedication reads, "in memory of Alice Van Vliet, January 11, 1874 - September 6, 1935, from her friends, to her friends".

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two sub-series:
Sub-series 1.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains four poems, two plays, miscellaneous manuscripts, and a collection of handwritten copies of Ovid poems. They are all in good condition, though the handwritten material from the early part of the 20th century shows signs of brittleness and age, and can be difficult to read.

did.unittitle: Sub-series 1.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence. This includes drafts of letters written by Alice Van Vliet and letters she received while she studied Classical Moderations at Oxford University, England, and traveled throughout Europe during the post-WWI period, 1924-1927. They conclude with correspondence from her time as a teacher at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California. The tone of these letters is chatty and conversational, revealing personal experiences and the thrill of traveling and studying Classical Moderations at Oxford —referred to as “Mods” in many of her letters and diaries. The material in this Series is in good condition; most are not brittle, though some are difficult to read. Several of the letters were composed while on trains or boats and later typed. Because many of these letters are drafts, the paper is sometimes thin, the handwriting informal, and Van Vliet would often write on both sides of the paper in ink, which would seep through to the other side, thus making the letters almost entirely illegible.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Post Morrow (1896-1992), the daughter of James Howell Post (President of the National Sugar Refinery) and Louisa Henderson Wells, was a student at the Packer Collegiate Institute, graduating in 1916. Her mother was also a Packer Institute Alumna (class of 1880), as was her daughter Betsey (class of 1943). As a student, Elizabeth Post was active in Glee Club, school plays and debates. She also was active in the Student Settlement Association. She lived in Brooklyn Heights after graduation (Remsen Street), and from the evidence of programs in her papers; she continued to attend Packer functions in the decades following her graduation. She married Thomas Morrow in 1920 and was identified as a philanthropist in a newspaper clipping found in one of her hymnals. She was Vice President of the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute (years unknown). In 1937 she was appointed to the Packer Collegiate Institute Board of Trustees as the representative of the Association of Alumni. In the same clipping mentioned above, it was noted that she was the 6th woman appointed to the board, and her role was to help bring Packer policies in line with other similar educational institutions. Some time in the 1920s Elizabeth and Thomas Morrow established a homestead in Brookhaven, Long Island, where the Morrow family had formerly lived. The Post-Morrow Homestead in Brookhaven has become the headquarters of the Post Morrow Foundation, which was established by Elizabeth and Thomas to help preserve the rural character of Brookhaven and its surrounding areas in Suffolk County. Well into the 1970s Mrs. Morrow continued to give regularly, and often generously, to Packer funds.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Packer memorabilia, dating from 1880 to 1818. It includes some material (commencement program and issues of The Packer Alumna), which predate Post's school career. These items possibly belonged to her mother, who also attended Packer. Alternatively, Post may have acquired these items during her tenure as an officer of the Associate Alumnae or on the Packer Board of Trustees.

The bulk of the files date from Elizabeth Post’s school career and the years immediately following. These include school publications; a collection of programs of student plays, Glee Club performances, debates and school wide events (1909-1918); a 1913 exam; the script of “A Rose of Plymouth Town” with acting notes throughout for the role of Resolute Story, played by Elizabeth Post; programs of plays performed by the School Settlement Association; a handmade 1914 Packer calendar; and a Packer Anthem Book.

did.unittitle: Commencement Programs 1880 – 1887, and pre-1909 school items

physdesc.extent: in one box and four folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several hymnals seem to be Post Morrow’s personal copies, with editions from various years. The hymnals list Charles Taylor Ives and Raymond Huntington Woodman as editors. Most are in fragile condition. Several contained printed or mimeographed lyric sheets. The hymnals sometimes contain ephemera, including painted place cards (including ones for “Mrs. Pratt,” “Mrs. Morrow” and “Dr. Brockway”), a clipping announcing the appointment of Morrow to the Packer Board of Trustees, and the Annual Sermon to the graduating class of 1925.

did.unittitle: Hymnals (includes lyric sheets and sermon) (6 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series include files of major events at Packer, or materials around a specific topic that were kept separate by Elizabeth Post Morrow in her original files. File 1 contains 75th anniversary materials (1928) including invitations, programs around various celebratory events, as well as a pamphlet history of Packer 1853-1928. File 2 has a few items related to a dinner in honor Dr. John H. Denbigh (1937). Dr. Denbigh retired that year as president of the Packer Collegiate Institute. File 3 contains clippings, invitation, and programs for the Edwin Jasper Memorial Lectures (1938-1937). Robert Moses was the speaker in 1939. These are fragile and need encapsulation. File 4 contains Centenary Celebration programs, invitations, lyric sheets and other related from 1945. File 5, Class of 1916 Material, contains items found in an envelope related to the class of 1916, including invitations to special graduation events in 1916, dance cards, and programs. This file also has notes and clippings related to reunions in 1937 and 1966.

did.unittitle: Dinner to Honor Dr. John H. Denbigh

physdesc.extent: in one box and three folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk dates of the material are 1937–1972. The files contain a mixture of materials generated by the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Packer itself, and personal notes from the school administration or other alumna to Elizabeth Post Morrow. The majority of the records are fund raising letters, reports, brochures and event ephemera. Some of these materials are informative, especially letters and reports to the Associate Alumni written by Packer president John F. Skillman. Topics cover the financial troubles or well being of the school, enrollment concerns (1952), closing of the junior college (1971) and the decision to become a co-educational school (1972). There are a few hand written memos relating to Associate Alumnae business, mostly dating from late 1930s to the early 1950s. Other materials include invitations and programs of school events, reprints of speeches by Packer presidents, promotional brochures (some of these have photographs), newspaper clippings covering Packer news, announcements of changes in administration, and expansion of the school facility. Materials of particular interest are: a report card from 1930s reflecting concerns with appearance and deportment, a 1972 Coeducation Study Preliminary Report, a study on the junior college, and a 1969 letter from President on changes being considered to the school. There are several issues of the Packer Times from 1972–1973.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the student papers of Susan Losee (Nichols), dating from 1865 to 1869. Papers include written exams, essays, lecture notes and exercise books, including a handwriting practice book, and cover a wide range of subjects, including French history, mythology, Latin , astronomy, geography, physiology, grammar/spelling, etc. Also included is a personal scrapbook of classmates’ written entries. Eight illustrated “Reward of Merit” cards, awarding student achievement, are included, along with a Certificate of Academic Scholarship issued by Packer for admission to the University of the State of New York, dated 1869.
